Throughout the year, the patchwork of hues you can see from this vantage point is always changing,

The Davi Valley is not just a pretty place to look at. It is one of only a handful of biosphere
reserves in the UK, an international conservation designation created to promote and demonstrate a
balanced relationship between humans and the biosphere. From the Cessail Oak woodlands in the
valley tops to the estuary below, the area is rich in wildlife. And as Clive Faulkner,
Conservation Manager for the Montgomeryshire Wildlife Trust, explains,
for a major estuary it is curiously underdeveloped. Unusually, there aren't actually buildings. There
isn't a marina, there isn't a factory, there isn't a town. Most, if you look at most of the valleys,
most of the estuaries in the UK, they end in a town, they end in an oil refinery, they end in
a marina. And it's not the case there. So actually, if you look at the whole valley as a unit,
it's a beautiful, unique place. And it's basically unspoiled. And yet there are people there who are
living with the landscape. And that's a really special thing. Retrace your steps back to the new
style. But do not cross it. Instead turn right and head downhill. When the slope eases, bear right
towards the left hand side of Glaslin Lake, rather than following the fence line. And your route down
